awd_titl_txt: RUI: SYNTHESIS, STRUCTURE, AND REACTIVITY OF ALKYNE-LINKED OLIGOPHENYLENES AND CYCLOPHENYLENES
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Derik K. Frantz of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo is developing three-dimensional, cyclic and multicyclic molecular structures. These unique molecules are of fundamental interest as the researchers explore their unusual properties and investigate their potential applications in functional materials. A versatile synthetic strategy permits the creative design and construction of a wide variety of these molecules, which contain nanometer-scale rings that are clamped or tethered by short, linear linkers (alkynes). Outside of the laboratory, the Broader Impacts of this work support Professor Frantz's efforts to improve student success and increase inclusivity in organic chemical education through the production and presentation of video lessons to help students understand challenging concepts and to supplement an active, engaging classroom experience.

Professor Frantz and his undergraduate research group aim to synthesize and investigate a variety of alkyne-linked oligophenylenes and cyclophenylenes. The synthetic methodology incorporates alkyne linkers as templates for the generation of phenylene- and ethynylene-based macrocyclic and multicyclic systems. In the targeted structures, alkyne groups internally link macrocycles to form structures with constrained molecular geometries. The researchers are studying the effect that this constrain imparts on the molecules' static and dynamic structures and on their reactivities and properties. The constrained targets include highly strained systems, twisted and helical structures, and designs possessing interlinked units. To construct these molecules, the researchers will apply a synthetic strategy that features robust, transition metal-catalyzed, C-C bond-forming reactions. This transferrable and modifiable approach will generate a variety of creative and unprecedented structures. Undergraduate students contributing to this project are to have an immersive research experience and gain significant practical scientific training and familiarity with advanced organic chemical concepts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Synthesis of macrocyclic molecular constructs and investigation of their properties continue to garner significant interest in the chemical community. Strained macrocycles comprising aryl groups and alkynes often exhibit unusual properties and reactivities that are not observed in their acyclic counterparts. Exploration of these fascinating molecular designs expands our understanding of relationships between chemical structure and properties and informs the potential creation of new organic materials for a variety of applications.

This award supported research experiences for undergraduate students who synthesized unprecedented molecular structures and made several key discoveries: (1) experimental and computational studies indicate that cyclization of a strained meta-quaterphenylene acetylene likely occurs by a Diels–Alder reaction and is the first example of a Diels–Alder reaction at the bay region of a biphenyl group; (2) a tetrakis(2-chlorophenyl) derivative of diphenylacetylene undergoes nickel-mediated, four-fold intramolecular arylation of the alkyne group to give a remarkable, chiral structure; (3) Eglinton coupling of diethynyl derivatives of quaterphenylene generates macrocycles that undergo cyclization of their ortho-ethynylbiphenyl moieties to form macrocyclic, linked polycyclic conjugated hydrocarbons; (4) subjecting 2,2’-dibromobiphenyl to Suzuki reaction conditions with 2-formylbenzeneboronic acid generates tribenzotropol in high yields in an apparent example of intramolecular addition of a transient organopalladium species to an aldehyde.

The Broader Impacts of this project provided outstanding research experiences and training for twenty-two undergraduate students who developed excellent practical laboratory skills, including regularly applying water- and oxygen-free techniques. Through participation in these cutting-edge research projects, students also gained a solid understanding of organic chemical concepts and scientific communication. Another important impact of this work was the development of a series of educational videos, which are publicly available on YouTube. These videos help students properly prepare for their laboratory courses both at the PI’s home institution and beyond and are useful educational materials for the students or other curious members of the public who have an interest in organic chemistry but do not have access to a laboratory.


Last Modified: 11/21/2024
Modified by: Derik K Frantz
